title: MCP on Innovative and Connected Public Administrations
callTitle: Accelerating the Best Use of Technology
descriptionByte:
Expected Impact:

To effectively progress in developing and testing elements necessary for cross-border digital public services and pave the way towards seamless digital public services across the Union.

Objective:

The objective of the action is to allow Member States to work together, jointly identify needs and develop interoperability assets needed for cross-border digital public services, leveraging collective resources and expertise to achieve impactful results unattainable by single entities. The MCP supports the implementation of the Interoperable Europe Act by enhancing collaboration among stakeholders to contribute to the priorities of the Interoperable Europe Agenda, focusing on improving public services through seamless data exchange and addressing interoperability challenges. This effort aligns with the EU’s Digital Decade goal of ensuring full online access to public services and secure eID solutions by 2030.

Scope:

Citizens and businesses demand user-focused, inclusive digital public services that are accessible through multiple channels and align with European values. Public administrations are urged to become more data-driven and adopt integrated approaches while ensuring safe use of AI.

The MCP aims to improve interoperability by supporting existing and developing new solutions, enhancing collaboration among stakeholders for cross-border services, and scaling up innovative solutions. It also focuses on implementing EU policies, particularly on AI and Data Spaces, to streamline processes and improve interoperability across networks with common data standards.

summary: CALL FOR PROPOSALS – Small Grants for Grassroots Coding Projects in Belgium and the Netherlands as part of EU Code Week
content: CALL FOR PROPOSALS – Small Grants for Grassroots Coding Projects in Belgium and the Netherlands as part of EU Code Week

beneficiaryAdministration:
Grants will be given to the top successful applicants. The total grant given will be a minimum of €250 and maximum €1000, depending on the project’s request and the availability of funds. The available total budget that be distributed this round is €6,319. The selection will be based on the quality and impact of the proposals. Proposals will be assessed based on criteria such as clarity, feasibility, educational impact, and alignment with EU Code Week’s objectives.  

Eligibility  

Eligible applicants include all schools with students up to the age of 18 years old in any category or system of official Belgian or Dutch education. Organizations affiliated with schools can prepare a submission, but it always has to be a school who is the legal entity submitting for the grant. Legal entities require a registration in the ‘Staatsblad’ or with the ‘Kamer van Koophandel’. As such they should have a VAT number. 

Application Process  

Interested organizations are invited to submit a project proposal by March 15th, 2026. Applications must be submitted through https://forms.gle/nHbJjGBa7Cwx97Yv5.

Each applicant needs to present:  

  1. A description of the project, its objectives, and expected impact.  
  2. Details on the implementation plan, timeline, and resources required.  
  3. Information about the applicant organization, including relevant experience.
description:
Purpose and Scope  

The purpose of this Call for Grants is to identify and support impactful grassroots coding projects aligned with EU Code Week’s mission to promote coding, computational thinking, and digital skills across Europe.  

Key objectives include:  

  1. Enabling the development of innovative and scalable coding activities.  
  2. Supporting initiatives that integrate coding into educational contexts and foster engagement.  
  3. Encouraging community involvement and fostering collaboration among stakeholders.  
  4. Prioritizing projects that bridge the gender gap and promote diversity in STEM education.

summary: Innovation Funding for Estonian Cybersecurity Companies for developing innovative, high value-added products and services
content: Innovation Funding for Estonian Cybersecurity Companies for developing innovative, high value-added products and services

beneficiaryAdministration:
To apply, the following requirements must be met:

  1. The applicant is a company registered in the Estonian Commercial Register.
  2. The company’s business activity is related to cybersecurity products and/or services.
  3. The applicant’s principal activity falls under EMTAK 2025 Division K, including:
  4. Telecommunications
  5. Computer programming
  6. IT consulting
  7. Computing infrastructure and other information service activities
  8. The company’s EMTAK code must be compatible with the scope of the support scheme
  9. The project must involve at least one partner, such as a research or development institution
  10. All project activities must take place within the EU or EEA (EU Member States, Norway, Iceland, or Liechtenstein)
  11. Both the applicant company and the entity controlling the project partner must be registered in the EU or EEA.

To apply, the following steps must be completed:

  1. Identify a suitable research or development partner - Find a research or development institution that matches your project idea
  2. Discuss the project idea with the partner - Agree on the project scope, objectives, expected results, and roles
  3. Request a price quote - Obtain a formal price offer from the research or development institution for their planned work
  4. Prepare the project plan - Describe the project objectives, activities, timeline, budget, and expected impact
  5. Complete the application form - Fill in the required information in the E-grant self-service environment
  6. Submit the application and supporting documents - Upload the project plan, price offer, and all other required documents in E-grant and submit the application.
description: The grant will help strengthen cooperation between research and development institutions and companies or organisations involved in the development of cybersecurity products and services, in order to carry out innovation and development activities in the field of cybersecurity.

callTitle: Innovation Funding for Estonian Cybersecurity Companies for developing innovative, high value-added products and services
furtherInformation:
A company may apply for support in the amount of €60,000 to €100,000 of the total cost of the product development project. The grant amounts to 70% of the total project costs for micro and small enterprises, 60% for medium-sized enterprises, and 50% for large enterprises.

The grant is targeted at projects carrying out innovation and development activities in the following areas:

  1. cybersecurity automation
  2. the use of artificial intelligence in cybersecurity
  3. tools and strategies for the transition to quantum-resistant cryptographic algorithms
  4. cybersecurity of space technologies

The call deadline of 2 December 2026, may be extended depending on the availability of funding.

Further information on the Innovation Funding is provided by RIA (Estonian Information System Authority) and EIS (Estonian Business and Innovation Agency) websites.

summary: Open calls (FSTP) for CYberSynchrony project: Open Call 1: Infrastructure Resilience & Operational Readiness; Open Call 2: Compliance, Innovation & Regulatory Advancement; Open Call 3: Mutual Assistance & Cyber Collaboration Among Member States
content: Open calls (FSTP) for CYberSynchrony project: Open Call 1: Infrastructure Resilience & Operational Readiness; Open Call 2: Compliance, Innovation & Regulatory Advancement; Open Call 3: Mutual Assistance & Cyber Collaboration Among Member States

beneficiaryAdministration:
Proposals must be submitted only via the dedicated online platform (registration required, more details at https://cybersynchrony.eu/open-calls/). Submissions are accepted exclusively through this platform during the call’s opening period; late submissions or submissions via other means (e.g., email) are not accepted and will not be evaluated. Proposals must be written in English and submitted as a PDF. The core proposal document must be concise and must not exceed 10 pages (excluding any required annexes); proposals exceeding the page limit are ineligible and will not be evaluated. All required documents must be uploaded through the submission platform before the call deadline.

After the deadline, the Open Call Management Team (OCMT) performs an eligibility check, including automatic filtering to discard non-eligible proposals. Eligibility conditions may differ per open call, and only eligible proposals proceed to evaluation.

Eligible proposals are evaluated by independent external experts operating under confidentiality and conflict-of-interest rules. Each proposal is assigned to two external reviewers, who produce individual Evaluation Summary Reports (ESRs). Proposals are scored on a 0–5 scale per criterion (there will be 4 criteria and the maximum score for a proposal will be 20), with a threshold of 3/5 per category required to qualify for selection. For more information please refer to the “Open Call applicant guidelines”, located at https://cybersynchrony.eu/open-calls/.
description:
CYberSynchrony delivers an integrated, modular cybersecurity framework, combining advanced threat intelligence, automated response systems, and secure channels for cross-border collaboration:

a.   Support rapid detection and mitigation of cyber incidents, continuous risk monitoring, and effective information sharing between Member States and key stakeholders.

b.     Emphasise on fostering a cybersecurity-aware environment, offering targeted training, awareness campaigns, and practical tools that support organisations in aligning with evolving regulatory requirements (i.e. NIS2 Directive).

Through its 3.55m € Open Call (which will comprise 3 different open calls, see more information below), CYberSynchrony invites SMEs, innovators, and specialised teams to contribute tools, services, and practices that can enhance the project’s platform and expand its applicability across different sectors. This financial support mechanism offers the opportunity to integrate new capabilities into real-world pilots, ensuring the solutions developed are practical, scalable, and relevant to the security needs of Europe’s digital infrastructure.


Open Call 1: Infrastructure Resilience & Operational Readiness

Scope

This call targets the enhancement of cybersecurity infrastructure and operational readiness specifically within sectors governed by the NIS2 Directive—energy, transport, drinking water supply and distribution, and manufacturing. It supports solutions aimed at improving sector-specific resilience against cyber threats and enabling rapid, coordinated responses.

Priority Areas (all priority areas must be met)

  1. Strengthening Sector-specific Cybersecurity Operations: Support initiatives that establish or amplify operational cybersecurity hubs tailored to the unique needs of energy, transport, water supply, and manufacturing sectors, ensuring sector-specific threat intelligence gathering, rapid incident response, and best practice sharing.
  2. Enhanced Threat Intelligence and Risk Assessment for NIS2 Domains: Channel funds towards projects that aim to develop or adapt advanced threat intelligence platforms specific to the challenges of energy, transport, drinking water, and manufacturing sectors. Focus on real-time monitoring, predictive analytics, and proactive threat hunting tailored to the infrastructures of these domains.
  3. Promotion of Cybersecurity Awareness in NIS2 Sectors: Fund campaigns and training programs tailored to professionals and stakeholders in the energy, transport, water, and manufacturing sectors. Promote best practices, risk mitigation, and cybersecurity hygiene specific to each sector's challenges and requirements.
  4. Supporting Cross-sector Collaborations: Encourage projects that foster inter-sector collaboration, ensuring best practices in one domain (e.g., energy) can be shared and adapted for others (e.g., transport or water supply).

Linked CYberSynchrony Objectives (see section 2.4): #1, #3, #6, #7, #8

Mandatory KPIs to be defined by the applicants (additional KPIs may be defined):

  1. Number of essential entities supported
  2. Number of threat assessments/risk scenario analyses carried out
  3. Number of risk monitoring services provided


Open Call 2: Compliance, Innovation & Regulatory Advancement

Scope

This call addresses the regulatory landscape and supports innovative cybersecurity solutions specifically tailored for sectors covered by the NIS2 Directive—energy, transport, drinking water supply and distribution, and manufacturing.

Priority Areas (all priority areas should be met)

  1. Encouraging Regulatory Compliance in NIS2 Sectors: Dedicate funding to support initiatives focusing on achieving and maintaining compliance with cybersecurity regulations specific to energy, transport, water supply, and manufacturing sectors within the EU.
  2. Boosting Innovations Tailored to NIS2 Domains: Support research and development projects addressing the unique cybersecurity challenges and needs of the specified sectors. This includes creating sector-specific tools, technologies, and strategies ensuring a secure operational environment.
  3. Promotion of Cybersecurity Awareness in NIS2 Sectors: Fund campaigns and training programs tailored to professionals and stakeholders in the energy, transport, water, and manufacturing sectors. Promote best practices, risk mitigation, and cybersecurity hygiene specific to each sector's challenges and requirements.
  4. Supporting Cross-sector Collaborations: Encourage projects that foster inter-sector collaboration, ensuring best practices in one domain (e.g., energy) can be shared and adapted for others (e.g., transport or water supply).

Linked CYberSynchrony Objectives (see section 2.4): #6, #8, #9

Mandatory KPIs to be defined by the applicants (additional KPIs may be defined):

·Number of penetration tests provided

·Number of essential entities supported

·Number and nature of vulnerabilities discovered


Open Call 3: Mutual Assistance & Cyber Collaboration Among Member States

Scope

In an era where cybersecurity threats transcend borders, the collaboration between Member States (MS) is pivotal. This Open Call seeks to foster a more integrated and united approach to cybersecurity, emphasizing mutual assistance, best practice sharing, and coordinated response mechanisms among MS.

Priority Areas (Proposals must clearly address at least one of the listed objectives and detail how the initiative will enhance mutual assistance among Member States)

  1. Establishing Unified Threat Intelligence Platforms: Develop or enhance platforms that facilitate real-time sharing of threat intelligence between MS, ensuring a collective response to emerging cyber threats.
  2. Joint Cybersecurity Exercises & Training: Organize joint cybersecurity exercises simulating cross-border incidents, aiming to test and improve the collective response capabilities of MS. Promote training sessions where MS can share their unique experiences, tools, and best practices, ensuring that all states benefit from individual advancements.
  3. Incident Response Coordination: Create or amplify mechanisms that enable rapid coordination between MS when a cybersecurity incident impacts multiple countries. Develop shared playbooks and protocols to guide coordinated responses, ensuring faster containment and mitigation of threats.

Linked CYberSynchrony Objectives (see section 2.4): #2, #4, #5

Mandatory KPIs to be defined by the applicants (additional KPIs may be defined):

  1. Number of potential number of users covered per test/ exercise
  2. Number of cross-border actions/exercises

summary: IST GreenChips-EDU Research Studentships
content: IST GreenChips-EDU Research Studentships

beneficiaryAdministration:
IST awards two Research Studentships in the research field of Electronics within the IST/UPC Double Degree Programme. The Research studentship will have the duration of 12 months and the workplace will be at UPC Escola Tècnica Superior d'Enginyeria de Telecomunicació de Barcelona, starting on the 18th of February, 2026.

Applications are open from January 1st – February 28th 2026 for two Research Studentships within the framework of project GreenChips-EDU, 1018P.06429, financed under the Partnership Agreement PT2020, under the following conditions:

Scientific Area: Electronics

Admission Requirements:

According to Article 6 of FCT Regulation for Research Studentships and Fellowships (Reg. nr. 950/2019):

a) To be enrolled in the MSc in Electrical and Computing Engineering at IST (ULisboa) and

b) Applicants must have been granted a place within the IST/UPC Double Degree programme (https://telecos.upc.edu/ca/mobilitat/international-partners/double-degree-partners#autotoc-item-autotoc-4 or https://aai.tecnico.ulisboa.pt/files/sites/52/upc_meec.pdf)

Academic degrees (Bachelor or Masters degree) previously obtained and awarded by foreign higher education institutions shall be registered by a Portuguese institution, according to the Decree-Law nr. 66/2018, of August, 16th, and the Ordinance nr. 33/2019, of January, 25th. It is mandatory to provide the recognition certificate by submitting the application. More information is available on: https://www.dges.gov.pt/pt/pagina/reconhecimento?plid=374

c) The applicants must hold the nationality of:

EU Member States or countries associated with the Digital Europe Programme (e.g., countries in the European Economic Area - EEA: Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway - and other nations that have signed association agreements, including those from the Western Balkans and Eastern Europe: Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, Moldova, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Serbia, Turkey, and Ukraine).

Workplan: 2nd year of the dual-degree: Master in Electrical and Computer Engineering with specialization in Electronic Circuits and Systems (IST) and Master’s degree in Electronic Engineering (Escola Tècnica Superior d'Enginyeria de Telecomunicació de Barcelona)

Legislation and Regulations: Statute of Scientific Research Fellow, approved by Law nr. 40/2004, of August 18, as worded by Decree-Law nr. 123/2019, of August 28; FCT Regulation for Research Studentships and Fellowships, available on https://www.fct.pt/apoios/bolsas/docs/RegulamentoBolsasFCT2019.pdf and https://dre.pt/application/file/a/127230968.

Workplace: The position's workplace will be at UPC Escola Tècnica Superior d'Enginyeria de Telecomunicació de Barcelona.

Duration: The research fellowship(s) will have the duration of twelve months. It’s expected to begin on the 18th of February, 2026.

Monthly maintenance allowance: According to the values applicable to FCT Research Fellowships abroad, the monthly maintenance allowance is set at €1,309.64, with payment made by wire transfer or cheque, as chosen by the Fellow.


Selection methods:

The evaluation of the applications will be carried out by the selection committee, which will consider the academic merit of the candidate as well as gender and socioeconomic inequalities in the field of Electronic Engineering. Each application will be assigned a score based on an evaluation system of 35 points structured in 6 blocks:

1. (20 points) Academic performance (r1)

Academic performance will be measured in terms of the average grade (g) of a completed bachelor's degree (or master's degree) that is directly linked to the field of electronic engineering or is directly connected to or has a special relevance to the objectives of the GreenChips-EDU project.

The calculation will be made by comparing the average grade (g) of the applicant with the average grade (gavg) obtained by all students who have completed the same bachelor's or master's degree in the last 5 years. In the case of degrees where there are not 5 completed promotions, as many promotions as available will be taken into account. Results will be normalized according to the minimum (gmin) and maximum (gmax) grades with which the indicated degree or master's degree can be obtained.

Additional considerations:

Applicants are solely responsible for providing the g, gavg, gmax and gmin values. In the event that the selection committee does not have any of this data, the application will receive 0 points in this section.

This information must be certified by the institution where the bachelor's or master's degree was obtained.

2. (5 points) Additional academic merits (r2)

This section assesses academic merits beyond those derived from their academic performance. Specifically:

(+1 point) If the student has completed a bachelor's or master's degree beyond that used for the calculation of r1.

 (+1 point) If the student has received a recognition or award for their academic activity. Honors are not included in this consideration.

   (+1 point) If the student is the author of a publication or poster in a conference or research journal.

   (+1 point) If the student demonstrates training in the field of sustainability or green electronics.

   (+1 point) If the student has developed projects related to the field of electronics beyond those required to obtain academic degrees. 

The concepts listed above are considered independently, with r2 being the sum of all those that the student fulfills in accordance with the documentation provided.

3. (5 points) Professional experience (r3)

The applicant's work experience in the field of electronic engineering will be valued. Depending on the number of accredited hours, the applicant will receive:

   (1 point) Between 100 hours and 500 hours.

   (2 points) Between 500 hours and 900 hours.

   (3 points) Between 900 hours and 1800 hours.

   (4 points) More than 1800 hours.

Applications that prove work experience in the field of sustainability or green electronics will receive an additional point.

4. (2 points) Positive gender discrimination (r4)

Two points will be assigned to female applicants, as a mechanism of positive discrimination that seeks to improve the presence of women in the MEE master's degree.

5. (2 points) Situation of vulnerability (r5)

The applicant may receive 2 points if they can prove that they are in a situation of socioeconomic vulnerability. This accreditation may be based on other grants already granted and that take this condition into account.

6. (1 point) Motivation and alignment with the call (r6)

The student's motivation and the alignment of the application with the objectives of the call will be valued with one point.

Composition of the selection Jury:

Prof. Marcelino Bicho dos Santos – Professor Catedrático do DEEC

Prof. Jorge Manuel Ribeiro Fernandes – Professor Associado com Agregação do DEEC

Prof. Fernando Manuel Duarte Gonçalves – Professor Auxiliar do DEEC

Announcement/ notification of the results: The final evaluation results will be communicated to all applicants by email.

Application deadline and formalization: The call is open from January 1st – February 28th 2026

It is mandatory to formalize applications with the submission of the following documents: i) B1 Form – Fellowship application (http://drh.tecnico.ulisboa.pt/bolseiros/formularios/ ); ii) Curriculum Vitae; iii) academic degree certificate, where applicable; iv) proof of enrollment at an academic degree course (Master, Integrated Master or PhD) or at a course that does not award an academic degree; v) motivation letter; vi) (for holders of Bachelor or Master degrees who are enrolled at a course that does not award an academic degree) declaration on honour that the applicant does not exceed with this contract an accumulated period of two years in this type of studentship, continuously or with interruptions.

Applications must be submitted to this email address: marcelino.santos@tecnico.ulisboa.pt.

Workplan: 2nd year of the dual-degree: Master in Electrical and Computer Engineering with specialization in Electronic Circuits and Systems (IST) and Master’s degree in Electronic Engineering (Escola Tècnica Superior d'Enginyeria de Telecomunicació de Barcelona)

Legislation and Regulations: Statute of Scientific Research Fellow, approved by Law nr. 40/2004, of August 18, as worded by Decree-Law nr. 123/2019, of August 28; FCT Regulation for Research Studentships and Fellowships, available on https://www.fct.pt/apoios/bolsas/docs/RegulamentoBolsasFCT2019.pdf and https://dre.pt/application/file/a/127230968.

Workplace: The position's workplace will be at UPC Escola Tècnica Superior d'Enginyeria de Telecomunicació de Barcelona.

Duration: The research fellowship(s) will have the duration of twelve months. It’s expected to begin on the 18th of February, 2026.

Monthly maintenance allowance: According to the values applicable to FCT Research Fellowships abroad, the monthly maintenance allowance is set at €1,309.64, with payment made by wire transfer or cheque, as chosen by the Fellow.


Selection methods:

The evaluation of the applications will be carried out by the selection committee, which will consider the academic merit of the candidate as well as gender and socioeconomic inequalities in the field of Electronic Engineering. Each application will be assigned a score based on an evaluation system of 35 points structured in 6 blocks:

1. (20 points) Academic performance (r1)

Academic performance will be measured in terms of the average grade (g) of a completed bachelor's degree (or master's degree) that is directly linked to the field of electronic engineering or is directly connected to or has a special relevance to the objectives of the GreenChips-EDU project.

The calculation will be made by comparing the average grade (g) of the applicant with the average grade (gavg) obtained by all students who have completed the same bachelor's or master's degree in the last 5 years. In the case of degrees where there are not 5 completed promotions, as many promotions as available will be taken into account. Results will be normalized according to the minimum (gmin) and maximum (gmax) grades with which the indicated degree or master's degree can be obtained.

Additional considerations:

Applicants are solely responsible for providing the g, gavg, gmax and gmin values. In the event that the selection committee does not have any of this data, the application will receive 0 points in this section.

This information must be certified by the institution where the bachelor's or master's degree was obtained.

2. (5 points) Additional academic merits (r2)

This section assesses academic merits beyond those derived from their academic performance. Specifically:

(+1 point) If the student has completed a bachelor's or master's degree beyond that used for the calculation of r1.

 (+1 point) If the student has received a recognition or award for their academic activity. Honors are not included in this consideration.

   (+1 point) If the student is the author of a publication or poster in a conference or research journal.

   (+1 point) If the student demonstrates training in the field of sustainability or green electronics.

   (+1 point) If the student has developed projects related to the field of electronics beyond those required to obtain academic degrees. 

The concepts listed above are considered independently, with r2 being the sum of all those that the student fulfills in accordance with the documentation provided.

3. (5 points) Professional experience (r3)

The applicant's work experience in the field of electronic engineering will be valued. Depending on the number of accredited hours, the applicant will receive:

   (1 point) Between 100 hours and 500 hours.

   (2 points) Between 500 hours and 900 hours.

   (3 points) Between 900 hours and 1800 hours.

   (4 points) More than 1800 hours.

Applications that prove work experience in the field of sustainability or green electronics will receive an additional point.

4. (2 points) Positive gender discrimination (r4)

Two points will be assigned to female applicants, as a mechanism of positive discrimination that seeks to improve the presence of women in the MEE master's degree.

5. (2 points) Situation of vulnerability (r5)

The applicant may receive 2 points if they can prove that they are in a situation of socioeconomic vulnerability. This accreditation may be based on other grants already granted and that take this condition into account.

6. (1 point) Motivation and alignment with the call (r6)

The student's motivation and the alignment of the application with the objectives of the call will be valued with one point.

Composition of the selection Jury:

Prof. Marcelino Bicho dos Santos – Professor Catedrático do DEEC

Prof. Jorge Manuel Ribeiro Fernandes – Professor Associado com Agregação do DEEC

Prof. Fernando Manuel Duarte Gonçalves – Professor Auxiliar do DEEC

Announcement/ notification of the results: The final evaluation results will be communicated to all applicants by email.

Application deadline and formalization: The call is open from January 1st – February 28th 2026

It is mandatory to formalize applications with the submission of the following documents: i) B1 Form – Fellowship application (http://drh.tecnico.ulisboa.pt/bolseiros/formularios/ ); ii) Curriculum Vitae; iii) academic degree certificate, where applicable; iv) proof of enrollment at an academic degree course (Master, Integrated Master or PhD) or at a course that does not award an academic degree; v) motivation letter; vi) (for holders of Bachelor or Master degrees who are enrolled at a course that does not award an academic degree) declaration on honour that the applicant does not exceed with this contract an accumulated period of two years in this type of studentship, continuously or with interruptions.

Applications must be submitted to this email address: marcelino.santos@tecnico.ulisboa.pt.

What are the Project Contents within the Scope of Support?

All projects must be related to coding or digital skills and align with the EU Code Week objectives. Projects that are compatible with the objectives of the grant support program are financed.

In this context, there are three main types of projects:

  1. Projects that develop an innovative approach or activity and include a pilot
  2. Projects that scale an existing approach or activity to new schools, school groups, and/or districts
  3. Projects aimed at increasing community engagement and visibility

What are the Selection Criteria?

Projects will be evaluated according to four dimensions and related categories:

  1. Presentation: The project is evaluated based on its clarity, comprehensiveness, and ability to effectively engage the target participants in its activities.
  2. Design Compliance: The project's objectives, viability, and internal coherence are assessed to ensure it aligns with its objectives and is consistent with the regional context.
  3. Digital Education, Coding, and Computational Thinking: The focus is on the centrality of digital, coding, and computational thinking in activities, as well as the appropriate and diverse use of tools and programming languages.
  4. Quality of the Applied Project: The educational relevance of the project is assessed on the basis of the provision of materials that enable local and wider synergies, replication and adaptation.

Selection Process

The grant support application form will be followed by the Young Success Education Foundation and will remain open for at least two months.

At the end of the second month, it will be evaluated by independent jury members.

After the completion of the evaluation process by the independent jury members, positive or negative information will be given about the result of the grant support for all applications.

content: TUS Open Call #2

beneficiaryAdministration:
TUS Open Call 2 Offer 

The DigiWind TUS Open Call 2 is for a partial stipend scholarship to complete a master's by Research in an area relevant to the digitalisation of Wind and Energy Systems.    

Applicants can choose between two Masters options: 1. Masters of Science (MSc) in Electrical Power Systems (By Research) or 2. Masters of Science (MSc) in Wind Energy Systems (By Research). 

It is envisaged that up to five scholarships will be awarded, with successful applicants receiving a partial stipend of €1,000 per month for a maximum duration of 18 months, or until the end of the DigiWind project in December 2027. Successful applicants will also be eligible for a fee waiver, which i covered by TUS and is not financed by the EU FSTP grant. 

The successful candidates will be based at the TUS Campus in Limerick, Ireland studying in-person with access to online classes.  

Applicants profile 

The programme is aimed at existing technological, electrical, mechanical, scientific, or engineering professionals, and those migrating from associated disciplines. Knowledge of software programming and statistical tools is expected.  

Preference will be given to applicants with skills and experience in electrical power systems, electrical controls, substation/grid operations, wind turbine technology, wind farm resource monitoring and modelling, and/or operations and maintenance, as well as a strong motivation to pursue a career in Wind and Energy Systems.  

Academic/Professional Background: Applicants must hold a bachelor's degree, or master's degree, or PhD and/or be an industry professional who can contribute directly to the digitalisation of the renewable energy sector.  

Nationality: Applicants must be a passport holder of an EU Member State, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, Moldova, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Serbia, Türkiye, Ukraine, Albania, European Economic Area (EEA) countries (Iceland, Norway, Liechtenstein).   

Submission process 

Step 1: Get Started on the F6S Platform 

  1. Create your applicant account on the F6S platform: https://www.f6s.com/digiwind-tus-open-call-2/apply 
  2. Carefully read the entire Guidelines for Applicants document to fully understand the terms and conditions of this Open Call.  
  3. Familiarise yourself with the administrative questions by reviewing the Application Form. This document is for reference only; your application must be completed directly on the F6S platform.  

Tip: We will also run two live webinars during the application period. Details will be announced on the DigiWind website, social media and F6S page.

Step 2: Prepare Your Documentation  

Gather and prepare all required supporting documents in PDF format. Ensure no printing restrictions are applied to your files.  

Mandatory Documents:  

  1. Degree Awards: Original or certified copy of your Degree Awards.  
  2. Transcripts of Results: Transcripts for your higher education degrees.  
  3. Curriculum Vitae (CV)
  4. English Language Competency: Certified evidence of English language competency (e.g., TOEFL, IELTS), meeting the specified minimum scores.   

Once selected, you will sign:  

A TUS Student / Supervisor Learner Agreement. Get familiar with the document to understand terms and conditions. 

A Declaration of Honour. Document declaring your acceptance of all Open Call conditions. 

Documents can be found at the official TUS Open Call 2 website. 

Step 3: Choose Your Master preference  

Within the F6S application form, you will be asked to rank your preferred Master's by Research programme Masters of Science (MSc) in Electrical Power Systems (By Research) or Masters of Science (MSc) in Wind Energy Systems (By Research).  

Step 4: Complete and Submit Your Application  

  1. Complete all sections of the application form directly on the F6S platform.   
  2. Upload all mandatory documents.  
  3. Thoroughly review your entire application before final submission.   
  4. Submit your application on the F6S platform by the official deadline.  

Evaluation process  

Submission will be done EXCLUSIVELY via F6S platform. A full list of applicants will be drafted containing their basic information for statistical purposes and clarity (which will be also shared with the EC for transparency). 

Applications will be evaluated by a panel of three Academics/Researchers in the IDEAM (Institute for Design Engineering, Artificial Intelligence and Advanced Manufacturing) Research Institute, chaired by the Institute Director following the evaluation criteria. For more information on the selection and evaluation process please refer to the Guidelines for Applicants. 

Results notification 

A ranked list of candidates will be prepared, and scholarships will be offered following the order of merit two weeks after the closing of the TUS Open Call 2. Successful applicants must indicate their intention to take up the offer within 1 month.   

Note: While all master's by research students will be admitted through the relevant Department, approval for admission will be subject to consideration by the relevant Faculty Research Committee which will make recommendations for acceptance or otherwise to the Graduate School for approval by Academic Council.  

Evaluation results will be compiled into an Evaluation Summary Report (ESR), which will be sent out to applicants. Depending on the evaluation outcome (acceptance or rejection), applicants will receive via email:   

Acceptance  

  1. An Evaluation Summary Report (ESR).  
  2. An acceptance letter with an invitation to the enrolment phase and following steps. 

Rejection

  1. An Evaluation Summary Report (ESR) for eligible applications that reached the internal evaluation phase.
  2. A rejection letter to ineligible applications.

For more details, please refer to the Guidelines for Applicants. 

Redress process 

Applicants who are not satisfied with the evaluation of their application, may within 5 working days of the result being issued submit a written appeal, which will be reviewed by a panel, chaired by the TUS Dean of Graduate Studies, the Project representative from TUS and one external member. Appeals are typically not allowed for disagreements with the academic judgment (Score) or if the decision was based on the applicants misunderstanding of the application. Valid grounds for appealing a postgraduate scholarship decision generally focus on errors in the assessment process or claims of discrimination.

beneficiaryAdministration:
Eligibility of costs:

Purchase of materials and equipment is allowed provided that these costs are proven to be related to the direct implementation of activities aimed at the final beneficiaries of the financing (the purchase of equipment as part of administrative costs is not allowed).

Administrative costs (project management costs, including financial management and communications, office supplies or other office costs) are eligible, but they cannot be more than 10% of the requested amount.

Evaluation criteria

All proposals that pass the eligibility check will be evaluated using criteria in five categories:

  1. Compliance with the program design of the initiative: compliance with the goals and priorities of Code Week; feasibility of activities, taking into account the schedule of activities and available professional, organizational and technological resources.
  2. Programming and Algorithmic Thinking Training: prioritising programming and algorithmic thinking, and will look at the extent to which these elements are at the heart of the activity – through the approaches used (such as block programming, programming without devices, etc.), programming languages and learning aids.
  3. Impact: the participation of more students, classes, schools, young people from the local community, as well as taking into account the local context. Special attention will be paid to girls' participation and the promotion of education in STEM fields (science, technology, engineering and mathematics).
  4. Quality of the proposal:

(1) Availability of educational elements such as methodological approaches and the relationship of the proposal with core academic disciplines (reading and mathematical literacy, data skills, digital literacy);

(2) use of impact assessment tools;

(3) building partnerships and joining forces within local communities, establishing cooperation networks to improve the efficiency of the initiative and involving the various stakeholders;

(4) sustainability of the idea - it will be evaluated positively if the idea has a long-term perspective and goes beyond the time range of the "week" itself;

(5) share resources and materials in order to promote sustainability (the possibility of implementing activities elsewhere, as well as openness of events to the local community).

  1. Presentation of the idea: clarity and comprehensiveness.

All other things being equal, priority will be given to projects involving the upper grades of secondary schools, as well as those involving leading teachers in CodeWeek.

Application Process

Project proposals should be sent by 23:59 on February 19, 2026, by filling in the application form.

Each applicant must submit via this form:

  1. Description of the project, its objectives and expected impact.
  2. Details of the implementation plan, timeline, and resources required.
  3. Information about the applicant organization, including relevant experience.

Each applicant must also attach a Project Budget as well as a Declaration of Consent. A sample of both documents can be downloaded from the links below:

The FSTP scheme CIF-NL 2025 focuses on 2 important sub-areas:

  1. Promoting crypto agility;
  2. Simplifying cybersecurity solutions.

The primary objective of this call round is to encourage Dutch organisations to develop innovative solutions that can contribute to strengthening national cyber resilience as a product and/or service, with applications in both government and business. To be eligible for the subsidy, projects must demonstrably contribute to one of the 2 sub-areas. For each of the two sub-areas € 1.250.000,- is available. Projects receive a minimum subsidy of € 60,000,- and a maximum subsidy of €100.000,-.

Project proposals can be submitted between the 9th of December 2025 9.00 CET and the 10th of February 2026 17.00 CET.

After the closing of the application period the project proposals will be evaluated based on 4 criteria. Project proposals can score between 1 and 5 points on each of the 4 criteria. Only project proposals that score minimal 3 points per criteria will be part of the ranking per sub-area. The more points a project proposal scores, the higher the place on the ranking.

content: 2. kolo - Výzva na získanie grantu od EU Code Week na podporu digitálnych inovácií v celej Európe

Grant details

Grants will be awarded to the 3 best successful applicants from Slovakia and the Czech Republic in the amount of EUR 2,500 for the first place, EUR 1,500 for the second place and EUR 1,000 for the third place.

The selection will be based on the quality and impact of the proposals. Proposals will be assessed on the basis of criteria such as clarity, feasibility, impact on education and consistency with EU Code Week objectives.

Eligibility:

Eligible applicants include (from Slovakia and the Czech Republic):

Interested parties are invited to submit a project proposal by February 15, 2026.

summary: G INP-UGA GreenChips-EDU Scholarship
content: G INP-UGA GreenChips-EDU Scholarship

beneficiaryAdministration:
GreenChips-EDU Scholarship


1.Purpose of the call


The GreenChips-EDU Project was launched in 2023 with the aim of nurturing talent in sustainable semiconductor technologies across Europe. The project seeks to educate students and researchers, equipping them with the knowledge needed for eco-friendly chip design, energy-efficient manufacturing, and innovative materials for the future of the EU.

As part of this initiative, Grenoble INP-UGA is pleased to announce a call for applications for scholarships to support Master’s students enrolled in, or planning to enrol in, relevant study programmes at Grenoble INP-UGA.

These scholarships are intended to provide financial support to students participating in academic collaborations through mobility programmes. The goal is to foster international cooperation and enrich the educational experience of students dedicated to advancing sustainable and innovative technologies in the electronics and microelectronics sectors.


2. Type of grants


The eligible expenses outlined in this document must be directly related to international mobility activities carried out at partner institutions participating in the GreenChips-EDU project. These mobility activities may also take place at industrial partner sites, including those that are not formal project partners, provided they align with the project's objectives and offer meaningful academic or professional engagement. In the field of sustainable electronics, for example, the mobility may take the form of professional training, enabling students to gain hands-on experience and develop practical skills within relevant industry settings.

GreenChips-EDU university partner institutions include the following;

Politecnico di Torino (PoliTo) – Italy

Technische Universität Darmstadt (TUDa) – Germany

Universitat Politècnica de Catalunya (UPC) – Spain

Graz University of Technology – TU Graz – Austria

Universidade de Lisboa (ULisboa) – Portugal

Carinthia University of Applied Sciences (CUAS) – Austria


GreenChips-EDU industry, SME and research partners include:

INESC ID – Portugal

Joanneum Research – Austria

Infineon Technologies Austria – Austria (and global)

Končar Inem – Croatia

Silicongate LDA – Portugal

Aedvices Consulting – France

RUSZ – Austria

Business Konsens OG – Austria

This funding call offers distinct types of grants. While students are permitted to apply for multiple grants, the total amount awarded to any individual must not exceed €5,000 regardless of the maximum limit assigned to each grant type. Financial aid may be provided in the form of reimbursement and/or a fixed amount granted in advance provided supporting documents are submitted.

The total funding available is €40,000

Only activities in related fields that end before 30 September 2027 are considered eligible.

Applications must be submitted by the following deadlines:

· 15 February 2026 23:59 (Brussels time)

· 1 July 2026 23:59 (Brussels time)

· 14 February 2027 23:59 (Brussels time)

· 1 June 2027 23:59 (Brussels time)


2.1. Coverage for internship fees

The grant will reimburse the beneficiary for the actual costs incurred, provided supporting documents are presented.

Scope of coverage:

· Transportation to and from the mobility destination.

· Living accommodation (rent).

2.2. Contribution to the costs of short-term mobility stays related to the Master's Degree

This grant type covers short-term mobility expenses that are not funded by the Erasmus+ Programme. Participation in Blended Intensive Programmes (BIPs) is specifically excluded.

Scope of Coverage:

The mobility period must typically be less than two months. The proposed activity must fall under one of the following eligible categories:

· Participation in international events, such as summer schools, workshops, or conferences.

· Courses beyond those offered by the partners, such as specialization courses, introductory training related to topics addressed in the Master’s thesis, or similar initiatives in the GreenChips-EDU thematic areas.

· Micro-credentials are also eligible for funding under the scholarship programme.

· Completion of a Master’s thesis at a foreign institution that is part of the GreenChips-EDU network.

· Professional training or internships at companies aligned with the GreenChips-EDU project.

Interactive formats offered by the GreenChips-EDU project can be found here: https://www.tugraz.at/projekte/greenchips-edu/news-events/event-calendar

Please find internship opportunities by the GreenChips-EDU project here: https://www.tugraz.at/projekte/greenchips-edu/student-opportunities/internship-offers

Covered Expenses:

Transport and accommodations.

2.3. Contribution to the expenses of long-term mobility stays related to the Master's Degree

This grant type provides additional financial support to ease the financial burden on students participating in long-term mobility programmes, particularly in double degree programmes.

Scope of Coverage:

The GreenChips-EDU programme may cover days that exceed the maximum Erasmus+ funded duration (e.g., a 6-month stay with only 5 months of Erasmus+ support).

For students enrolled in a double degree programme, GreenChips-EDU may provide living support during the first year of the programme while the students are at Grenoble INP-UGA .

Covered Expenses:

Transport and accommodation.

2.4. Contribution to expenses for scientific achievements during the mobility stay

This grant type supports research activities carried out by Master’s students working on their final projects, ideally during a period of mobility, which lead to a scientific publication aligned with GreenChips-EDU topics. All expenses must be incurred before 30 September 2027.

Scope of Coverage:

Scientific Publication Fees:

Up to €1,000 for full open-access publication in Q1 or Q2 journals.

Up to €500 for full open-access publication in Q3 or Q4 journals.

Presentation Materials:

Up to €100 for preparing posters for scientific congresses.

High-Level Conference Attendance:

Up to €1,500 for registration, travel and accommodation.

3. Who can apply for this grant?


3.1 Applicants criteria


To be eligible for the grant, applicants must meet all of the following conditions:

The student/applicant must be enrolled in an appropriate programme of study at Grenoble INP-UGA (Nanotech or SEI) or be pursuing a double degree programme that correlates with the project topics. They must also have applied for admission for the 2025/26 academic year or later.

The applicant must hold the nationality of:

EU Member States or countries associated with the Digital Europe Programme (e.g., countries in the European Economic Area - EEA: Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway - and other nations that have signed association agreements, including those from the Western Balkans and Eastern Europe: Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, Moldova, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Serbia, Turkey, and Ukraine).


4. Submission of applications

4.1 Application method and documentation

Applications can be submitted from the day after the scholarship call is published. Submissions will be accepted within the designated deadline (see deadlines or at the latest, until 1 June, 2027).

Applications must be submitted to the designated office at Grenoble INP-UGA. For applications or enquiries, please email panagiota.morfouli@grenoble-inp.fr.

Applications will be examined and evaluated by a committee comprising Panagiota MORFOULI, Clemens WINKELMANN, Cyrille CHAVET and Laurent MONTES.

The following documentation must be attached to the application form:

Cover Letter (Form A):

· Please submit a cover letter including the following: A brief introduction of yourself, highlighting your academic background / merits and current field of study. A description of your personal, social, economic, and professional circumstances, as well as your academic performance, that may be relevant to your scholarship application. If possible, please outline your future academic and career plans, including the field in which you wish to further pursue your academic studies.


Type of Grant (Form B) (see checklist below):

· Indicate the type(s) of grant you are applying for. Multiple selections are allowed if you are applying for more than one type.


Academic Grade Documentation:

· Please provide a document stating the average grade of your completed Bachelor’s or Master’s Degree in a field with a strong relevance to the objectives of the GreenChips-EDU project. (See Section 3.1)

The selection committee will check the average grades of all students on the same degree programme over the past year and use them as part of the selection criteria.

Documentary accreditation:

Applicants are responsible for providing supporting documentation for the situations described in the previous point, which are likely to refer to eligibility criteria or merit-based considerations. This includes:

· Documentation required for GPA and academic merits

You should provide the following:

o Official academic transcripts from your institution(s);

o Degree certificates or diplomas;

o GPA certification or a document explaining the grading scale (especially if it is not standard);

o Letters of recommendation (if applicable);

o Documentation for social and economic circumstances.

You may need to submit the following:

o Proof of income (e.g., tax returns, salary slips, or income certificates);

o Family income statements or affidavits;

o Social security or welfare documentation;

o Proof of residence in a disadvantaged area (if relevant);

o Medical or disability certificates (if applicable);

o Any official documentation supporting claims of economic hardship or social disadvantage.

· Accreditation of Mobility Placement

Applicants must provide:

o Proof that they have secured a mobility placement in one of the destinations approved by the call. If this has not yet been confirmed, they must provide a document signed by the Head of Studies of their institution and the Deputy Director of International Relations, endorsing the application.

This document must clearly state the destination of the mobility placement and the estimated length of time that the student will be abroad.


· Justification for Grants Type 2.2 – Short-term mobility stays

Applicants must submit a document justifying the relevance and benefits of the specialized training. This document must include the following:

o The name and description of the course or activity;

o Its purpose;

o The organizing institution;

o The location where the training takes place;

o Course registration confirmation or payment confirmation (if applicable).


· Documentation for Grants Type 2.4 – Scientific Achievement

Applicants must provide:

o A copy of the publication or poster related to the grant application;

o The complete reference number of the place of publication;

o All documentation to verify the publication-related expenses.


5. Selection criteria

The selection committee will evaluate the applications, considering the academic merit of the candidates, as well as gender and socioeconomic inequalities in the field of electronic engineering.

Each application will be assigned a score based on a 20-points evaluation system structured into six blocks:


5.1. (10 points) Academic performance (r1)

Academic performance will be measured in terms of the average grade (g) obtained for a completed Bachelor's or Master's Degree in electronic engineering or a subject directly connected to, or of special relevance to, the objectives of the GreenChips-EDU project.

This will be calculated by comparing the applicant’s average grade (g) with the average grade (gavg) obtained by all students who completed the same Degree the previous year.


Additional considerations:

Applicants are solely responsible for providing their grade point average (GPA). If the selection committee does not have this data, the application will receive 0 points in this section.

This information must be certified by the institution where the Degree was obtained.


5.2. (2 points) Additional academic merits (r2)

This section considers academic merits that go beyond academic performance. Specifically:

  1. (+1 point) If the student has received training in the field of sustainability or green electronics.
  2. (+1 point) If the student has developed projects related to electronics beyond what was required to obtain the academic degrees.  

The above concepts are considered independently, with r2 being the sum of all those that the student fulfills, in accordance with the provide documentation.


5.3. (2 points) Additional academic merits (r2)


The applicant's work experience in the field of electronic engineering will be valued. Depending on the number of accredited hours, the applicant will receive:


   (0.5 point) Between 100 hours and 500 hours.

   (1 points) Between 500 hours and 900 hours.

   (1.5 points) Between 900 hours and 1800 hours.

   (2 points) For more than 1800 hours.


Applications that demonstrate relevant work experience in the field of sustainability or green electronics will receive an additional point.

5.3. (2 points) Positive gender discrimination (r2)

Two points will be awarded to female applicants, as a form of positive discrimination to improve the representation of women on the Bachelor’s or Master's Degree programme.

5.4. (2 points) Situation of vulnerability (r3)

The applicant may receive two points if they can prove that they are experiencing socioeconomic vulnerability. This accreditation may be based on grants that have already awarded and take this condition into account.

5.5. (2 point) Motivation and alignment with the call (r4)

The student's motivation and how well the application aligns with the objectives of the call will be valued at one point.


Resolution of applications

Applications will be assessed by a selection committee.

The result will be announced electronically to all candidates.


Form A: Cover Letter

Please write a brief introduction to yourself, highlighting your academic background / merits and your current field of study. Describe your personal, social, economic, and professional circumstances, as well as your academic performance, in detail, bearing in mind what may be relevant to your scholarship application. If possible, please outline your future academic and career plans, including the field in which you wish to further pursue your academic studies + interest in sustainability

The applicant may receive two points if they can prove that they are experiencing socioeconomic vulnerability. This accreditation may be based on grants that have already awarded and take this condition into account.

The application process

Interested organizations are invited to submit a project proposal by 17:00hr on 15/02/2026. Applications must be submitted via this form HERE:Code Week

Each applicant must submit:

A description of the project, its objectives and expected impact.

Details of the implementation plan, timetable and resources required.

Information on the applicant organization, including relevant experience.

Each applicant must also upload a budget proposal for the project with their submission. The budget template can be downloaded from the call for projects web page. A selection committee will evaluate the proposals. Proposals will be evaluated according to the following criteria:

Eligibility: compliance with the defined conditions of participation.

Clarity and completeness of presentation: The quality of the project presentation in terms of clarity and completeness.

Coherence of design: The alignment of the project's objectives with Code Week's mission, the relevance of the proposed activities to these objectives and their suitability for implementation. The feasibility of the project is also examined in relation to the planned timetable and available resources (human, organizational and technological).

Education in programming and computational thinking: Analysis of the central place given to programming and computational thinking, taking into account the pedagogical approaches used (block languages, disconnected coding, etc.), the tools and technologies mobilized.

Project impact: Consideration is given to the scale of the initiative in terms of the number of classes, schools and categories of participants involved, as well as the local context. Particular attention is paid to the participation of girls and the promotion of STEM disciplines (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics).

Prioritization of projects: Wherever possible, priority will be given to initiatives involving secondary school pupils and integrating Code Week referent teachers in their implementation.

About ACHIEVE

Cloud and Networking Infrastructure, with the emergence of new trends like High-Performance Computing (HPC), are pivotal in driving Europe's key policy objectives like the Green Deal and digital transformation. The project, Advanced Cloud and High-performance computing Education for a Valiant Europe (ACHIEVE) is designed to enhance the quality of EU higher education in the domain of IT infrastructures and in particular HPC which is used to solve several complex questions in computational and data-intensive sciences. It offers a comprehensive approach, covering aspects from cloud computing, network architecture, to the advanced skills on HPC systems and their applications in answering complex questions like the simulation and modelling of physical phenomena (such as climate change, energy production, drug design, global security, and materials design), the analysis of large data sets (such as those in genome sequencing, astronomical observation, and cybersecurity), and the intricate design of engineered products, such as airplanes.

ACHIEVE aims to implement a double-degree master's program (ISCED Level 7, 120 ECTS) focusing on Cloud and Networking Infrastructure with two specializations that align with the strategic development of advanced, green, and efficient HPC systems. Additionally, it includes a minor in Innovation and Entrepreneurship. This program will be collaboratively designed and delivered by eight higher education institutions from six different countries, in partnership with major industry associations and companies specializing in cloud computing and HPC, along with an innovative SME for educational program delivery, a non-profit association, and EIT Digital, a leader in advanced digital skills education in Europe.

The master’s programme, also include a minor in Innovation and Entrepreneurship, are designed and delivered by a consortium consisting of 8 higher education institutions from 7 different countries, 2 innovative SMEs, 2 large enterprises, 3 leading research centre in Information Systems and EIT Digital, a pan-European organisation with in-depth knowledge and experience in the digital skills domain.

About the scholarships

ACHIEVE provides eligible students the financial support to take part to the education programme and offers scholarships to promote diversity in terms of gender, age, social and economic background. ACHIEVE’s scholarships allow the greatest number to have access to high-quality education in digital areas and increase diversity among students and future digital experts.

The students awarded a scholarship will be financially supported during their two years of studies in the double-degree in Masters’ programme offered by ACHIEVE.

Types of scholarships available 

Three types of scholarships are available: 

1.             half tuition fee waivers which cover 50% of the tuition costs. These funding schemes are designed to reduce financial barriers and support talented students in accessing high-quality education in key digital technology domains,  

2.             full tuition fee waivers, covering the entire tuition cost for both years, and  

3.             scholarships of excellence, which include a full tuition fee waiver and a monthly living allowance adjusted according to the cost-of-living index of the host country. 

The 2026-2028 fees are available here: https://masterschool.eitdigital.eu/admissions/fees  

How to apply

To apply to a ACHIEVE scholarship, candidates must enrol into ACHIEVE master’s programme. Only students enrolled and accepted in ACHIEVE Masters’ programme are eligible to financial support.

Enrolment is done via a single application portal. When enrolling to the master’s programme, applicants are given the opportunity to select 3 options as Entry University and 3 options as Exit University with order of priority. It gives students a wider choice: applicants who would not be accepted to their preferred education institution might still be accepted by another education institution. At the same time, as the capacity of each education institution is limited, the multiple-option offer ensures that a high number of applications is processed.

To apply to the ACHIEVE Master’s programme, candidates are required to upload into the application portal the following documentation:

1.    Degree Certificate/Diploma in its original language and translated into English (If your university does not provide this service, the translation has to be done by an authorised translator and his/her credentials, signature and stamps must be visible in the translated document). In case of ongoing studies, a statement certifying that you are in the final year of your studies. The statement must be written by the degree administration office (or equivalent department) confirming that you are enrolled on the final year of your education and giving your expected completion date. Note: If applying to Aalto as entry, your bachelor degree must be completed by July 31, 2026. 

3.    Mandatory technical prerequisites for admission to the programme: https://masterschool.eitdigital.eu/admissions/relevant-field-of-studies

4.    Official and stamped transcript of records in original language and translated into English. All courses taken must be included. Please scan the front and back of every document- all stamps and signatures must be fully visible. 

4.    Proof of English proficiency. The requirement of English proficiency will vary depending on the higher education institution/country selected by the applicant. Please refer to EITD Master School website ‘Admissions’ tab for more information. 

5.    Curriculum Vitae including details on your academic and professional career. 

6.    A letter of motivation (maximum 3 pages) to prove the innovative potential of the applicant and their need for financial support. In this letter applicants will be required to discuss and/or propose an entrepreneurial idea and to explain their financial situation and need for financial support. 

7.    Supporting documents regarding the applicant’s financial situation (e.g. credit report). 

8.    An official ID, such as passport or National ID.

Master School Scholarship allocation process

Applicants apply for the scholarships directly in their application for the Master School. The highest-ranking applicants are offered scholarships and are informed of the outcome at the same time as the Letter of Acceptance is sent, or within one week if a waiting list logic is applied. In this case, the first round of scholarships are announced at the time of the study offer, and the second round of scholarships are offered eight days later, when the deadline to accept/decline the offer has passed for students included in round one. The order of the waiting list is based on the applicants’ ranking as described below. 

The applicants go through several stages in the evaluation:

·      Pre-screening: performed by the Admission Officer at the Master School Office (KTH). Includes confirming that the university is recognised/accredited, GPA (Grade Point Average) of at least 70%, and Bachelor's degree is relevant

·      Evaluation and ranking by programme selection committee (see detailed description below). The selection committee for ACHIEVE consists of 8 members.

·      General requirements check: performed by the KTH admission office under the lead of the Admission Officer at the Master School Office. Includes confirmation of documents provided by the applicant. 

Selected students eligible to financial support will be required to sign an agreement with the EIT Digital Master School outlining their rights and obligations under the scholarship scheme. Failure to comply with the terms of this agreement may result in the termination of financial support and/or recovery of funds. In line with the provisions of the EU Digital Europe Programme Model Grant Agreement, the ACHIEVE project operates under the standard terms and conditions applicable to EU-funded projects, set out in Articles 12 (Conflict of Interest), 13 (Confidentiality and Security), 14 (Ethics), 17.2 (Visibility), 18 (Specific Rules for Carrying Out the Action), 19 (Information), and 20 (Record-Keeping) of the ACHIEVE Grant Agreement apply equally to all selected students eligible to financial support.

Eligibility requirements

ACHIEVE scholarships are available to nationals of one of the eligible countries:

  1. EU Member States (including overseas countries and territories (OCTs))
  2. Listed EEA countries and countries associated to the Digital Europe Programme (associated countries)

Only students enrolled and accepted in ACHIEVE Masters’ programme are eligible to financial support. When receiving their letter of acceptance and study offer, students will be notified of their scholarship allocation.

Evaluation and ranking by the programme selection committee

The selection committee for each programme consists of the local programme responsible from each participating university. One member is appointed the role of Programme Lead. All evaluation is noted in the application portal, administrated by the Master School Office. 

The Programme Lead assigns applicants to the selection committee members in the portal, based on the applicant’s university preferences stated in their application. Each member evaluates their assigned applicants and gives them a grade for each criterion. Based on the evaluation result, the Programme Leads assigns each applicant an entry university and an exit university as well as a final quantitative grade based on the two universities ranking of the applicant. 

All applicants are placed on a single, unified merit-based ranking list after the evaluation process. No separate ranking lists are created for women, RIS applicants, or any other subgroup. Gender and RIS status are used only as priority conditions in cases of equal final merit score. This ensures the process remains strictly merit-based while still supporting the diversity objectives of the programme.

Selection criteria

The criteria used when evaluating which candidates should be nominated for a scholarship, is the following:

Criteria

Weight

Evaluation range

Suitability of acquired Bachelor’s degree for intended study programme

Quality and recognition of home university

Study success[1]

Entrepreneurial and Innovative experience (CV, Recommendations)

Innovative and Entrepreneurial attitude (Letter of Motivation)

Overall evaluation of CV and application

1
